Background.text:
The higher the classification, the higher the likelihood of growth abnormalities
If physis fracture missed may lead to premature closure and bone growth arrest
It was previously taught that ligaments are stronger than bones in kids (and fractures were more likely than sprains), however newer studies (
to date in ankles
) contradict that assumption
[1]

Mnemonic.text:
S 1 - Slipped (through physis/growth plate)
A 2 - Above (physis with metaphysis fracture)
L 3 - Lower (physis  with epiphysis fracture)
T 4 - Through (physis, metaphysis and epiphysis fracture)
R 5 - Rammed (growth plate crushed)

tables.I (Slip): hypertrophic zone of physis (epiphysis separates from metaphysis)
tables.II (Above): Through physis and out through piece of metaphyseal bone
tables.IV (Through): Starts at articular surface and extends through epiphysis, physis, metaphysis

tables.I (Slip): Growing cells remain on the epiphysis in continuity with blood supply
tables.II (Above): Growing cells remain on the epiphysis in continuity with blood supply
tables.III (Below): fracture extends from epiphysis through physis

tables.I (Slip): Occurs mostly in infants and todlers
tables.V (Crush): Typically occurs at knee or ankle

Clinical_Features.text: Trauma with point tenderness over a non-closed (pediatric) physis

Type_1_(Slip).text:
Suspect if point tenderness over a physis
X-ray findings are subtle (epiphyseal displacement) or absent (clinical diagnosis)
Often radiograph negative

Type_2_(Above).text: X-ray shows triangular fragment of metaphysis with out injury to epiphysis

Type_3_(Below).text:
X-ray shows epiphyseal fragment not associated with etaphyseal fracture
Greater the displacement greater chance of vascular supply compromise

Type_4_(Both).text: fracture starts at articular surface and extends through epiphysis, physis, metaphysis

Type_5_(Crush).text:
X-ray shows physis compression fracture
May confuse for Type 1 injury: differentiation based on clinical presentation, history, and exam.
X-ray findings may be minimal

General_Fracture_Management.text:
Acute pain management
Open fractures
require immediate IV antibiotics and urgent surgical washout
Neurovascular compromise from fracture requires emergent reduction and/or orthopedic intervention
Consider risk for
compartment syndrome

Type_I.text:
Radiograph-negative ankle injury (peds)
Low risk mechanism
Most: Removable brace

[4]
[5]
Return to activities as tolerated by pain
Follow up with pediatrician

Type_II.text:
Most: Splint, ortho follow up
Ankle injury - Consider removable ankle brace
